q: Choose all requirements that are nonfunctional.
Choose all requirements that are functional.
Which of the following metrics does DevOps use to assess performance?
c: All of these answers are correct
a: All of these answers are correct

q: Which of the following principles is not associated with the Lean software development model?
Which of the following architecture patterns are an example of an event-driven architecture? (Choose 2)
How is the Agile software development model different from the waterfall model?
c: It has a higher degree of flexibility and speed
It has possibly multiple teams working independently with limited collaboration
All of these answers are correct
a: It has a higher degree of flexibility and speed

q: Unit testing is considered a type of _____.
c: Black-box testing conducted with no knowledge of the system
Gray-box testing conducted with some knowledge of the system
White-box testing conducted with full knowledge of the system
None of these answers are correct
a: White-box testing conducted with full knowledge of the system

q: What types of requirements specify what the software is doing in terms of, for example, business process or user interaction?
c: Neither. “What” the software is doing is not part of the design process

q: What is SDLC?
c: None of these answers are correct.

q: What is software architecture?
c: A set of structures explaining the software
The components or building blocks and their relations
The single source of truth for all business requirements related to the software being developed
All of these answers are correct
a: All of these answers are correct

q: Why do you need functional requirements?
c: To understand the functionality and business requirements of the application you’re building
All of these answers are correct
a: To understand the functionality and business requirements of the application you’re building

q: Which of the following attributes are true for a nonfunctional requirement? (Choose 2)
Which of the following is a type of nonfunctional requirement?
c: All of these answers are correct
a: All of these answers are correct

q: An important aspect of software quality assurance is peer code review, which may be looking at ______.
c: All of these answers are correct
a: All of these answers are correct

q: Which of these options is not a key practice of DevOps?
c: Create a cultural shift that combines development and IT operations.
Use CI/CD to reduce time required to update or deliver software.
Introduce small projects with increased collaboration.
Change culture such that DevOps teams aren’t measured on metrics.
a: Change culture such that DevOps teams aren’t measured on metrics.

q: Why do you need architectural patterns?
c: Architectural patterns introduce complexity and give the impression of sophisticated programming skills.
Architectural patterns ensure consistency of the code because it is a reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem within a given context.
There so many patterns, and you have to choose one.
All of these answers are correct.
a: Architectural patterns ensure consistency of the code because it is a reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem within a given context.

q: By developing a modular system, you make it easier to maintain, scale, and secure your system.
According to the ISO/IEC 25010, which of these are quality attributes?
Functional and nonfunctional requirements are _____.
c: Independent of each other because they are measured separately.
Considered in sequence functional then nonfunctional.
Considered in sequence nonfunctional then functional.
Considered hand in hand because you cannot measure nonfunctional requirements without understanding the functional or business requirements.
a: Considered hand in hand because you cannot measure nonfunctional requirements without understanding the functional or business requirements.

q: When is a design considered to be of high quality?
c: It processes data at high speed.
Nonfunctional requirements are clearly defined and are measurable.
a: Nonfunctional requirements are clearly defined and are measurable.

q: Which of the following attributes are considered part of maintainability according to ISO/IEC 25010?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What is coupling in a modular design?
c: A degree of independence between modules.
A measure of strength of the relationship among modules.
A degree of independence or dependence among modules.
All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: Heartbeats or “hello packets” are usually exchanged between redundant systems
c: To alert the standby system that the active system is no longer available.
And may require special processing and prioritization.
All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What do you strive to do with modularity?
c: Break the architecture into equal-size chunks.
Break the architecture into smaller chunks.
Break the architecture into smaller building blocks with clear functions and interactions.
None of these answers are correct.
a: Break the architecture into smaller building blocks with clear functions and interactions.

q: System A can perform 5,000 transactions per second, and system B is capable of 7,500 transactions per second. Is System B better in terms of performance as a quality attribute?
c: No. Quality attributes are related to the functions performed.
It depends on the specific transactions.
a: No. Quality attributes are related to the functions performed.

q: Which of the following is an example of data at rest?
c: Sending user information into the cloud
Synchronization between nodes of the in-memory database cluster
Video file being transcoded from one format into another using a web service
User credentials stored on the unencrypted file system
a: User credentials stored on the unencrypted file system

q: To improve availability in a design, what type of redundancy should you use?
c: Any of these answers are correct based on requirements and capabilities.
a: Any of these answers are correct based on requirements and capabilities.

q: What is horizontal scalability?
c: Adding additional servers to handle additional load.
All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: A software system that is modular is
c: split into small modules that each have clearly defined functionalities and clearly defined interfaces.
a: split into small modules that each have clearly defined functionalities and clearly defined interfaces.

q: Which of the following characteristic(s) should a quality attribute of a software design have? (Choose 2)
Availability can be expressed as
c: The number of hours when a system was reachable before it crashed.
The degree to which a system, product, or component is operational and accessible when required for use.
When a system was operational but not needed.
All of these answers are correct.
a: The degree to which a system, product, or component is operational and accessible when required for use.

q: The measurement of quality attributes is often qualified into six stages. Which is the correct order of these stages?
c: Source – Stimulus – System – Environment – Response – Measure
Stimulus – Source – Environment – System – Measure – Response
Source – Stimulus – Software – Environment – Response – Measure
Environment – System – Source – Stimulus – Metric – Response
a: Source – Stimulus – System – Environment – Response – Measure

q: The terms nonfunctional requirements and quality attributes are used interchangeably most of the time.
In a modular system, cohesion is (Choose 2)
c: a measure of the strength of the relationship among modules.
a measure of how elements are functionally related.
a: a measure of how elements are functionally related.

q: In a modular system, coupling is
c: a measure of the strength of the relationship among modules.
a measure of how elements are functionally related.
a: a measure of the strength of the relationship among modules.

q: Which of the following is a type of quality attribute?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: In modularity, it is considered a best practice when you do which of the following?
c: None of these answers are correct.

q: What is it essential to have for software maintainability?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What is observability, in simple terms?
c: A way to monitor the performance of a system through its users’ experience.
A way to detect system issues through the observation of its output.
A way to manage and monitor distributed applications.
All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: Performance is independent of other nonfunctional requirements such as availability or scalability.
Which SOLID principle states that higher-level modules should not depend on lower-level modules?
Which SOLID principle allows you, as a developer to use a subclass, as if you were dealing with an instance of the parent class?
Observability is said to have which three pillars?
Which of the following is used as an indicator of software performance?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: Which SOLID principle forbids a lower-level module from depending on a higher-level module?
What is SOLID?
c: Software design principles for building maintainable code
None of these answers are correct.
a: Software design principles for building maintainable code

q: What is lazy loading in caching?
c: A caching strategy where data is cached when necessary and not at initialization
A caching strategy where, in a lazy implementation, all data is loaded at initialization
A caching strategy where long results are split across multiple pages
A asynchronous request model where data is preemptively loaded
a: A caching strategy where data is cached when necessary and not at initialization

q: “Modules should be open for extension but closed for modification” is a definition of which of the SOLID principles?
Which SOLID principle requires you, as the developer, to avoid fat interfaces?
Which performance enhancements are commonly used in application design? (Choose two.)
What are the differences between relational and nonrelational databases? (Choose two.)
c: Relational databases can be key-value-stores where each key is associated with one value.
Relational databases store data in rows and columns like a spreadsheet.
Nonrelational databases are also known as NoSQL, where one type can be a document-oriented store.
There are hardly any differences between the two except that relational databases are commercial and nonrelational are mostly open source.
a: Relational databases store data in rows and columns like a spreadsheet.
Nonrelational databases are also known as NoSQL, where one type can be a document-oriented store.

q: Which item is not a characteristic of object-oriented programming?
Which of these factors affects round-trip time (RTT) from a software or application design perspective?
c: Time taken to travel between nodes
Amount of load the system is capable of handling
Time taken to complete a specific task
Time taken to complete a set of tasks
a: Time taken to complete a set of tasks

q: Which SOLID principle implies that a component should be usable or implementable through different interfaces but not modifiable?
Network congestion or packet drops are side effects of what network condition?
c: All of these answers are correct.

q: Which SOLID principle states that changing one class should not affect the functionality of any other classes?
What’s the relation between git and GitHub? Choose all that fit.
c: GitHub is an evolution of git—sort of like git 2.0.
GitHub provides a web interface to browse git repositories.
a: GitHub provides a web interface to browse git repositories.

q: In a branch and pull model, what’s the correct order of actions to get a change into the main branch of your remote repository? The remote repository is called origin.
c: Stage changes – Commit changes – Push changes to origin
Create new branch – Stage changes – Commit changes – Push to new branch in origin – Create pull request – Merge after PR was accepted
Commit changes – Push changes to origin – Merge into main
Push changes to origin – Commit changes – Merge into main branch
a: Create new branch – Stage changes – Commit changes – Push to new branch in origin – Create pull request – Merge after PR was accepted

q: You are on a branch called update-readme and have just committed your changes. Which command can be used to push the commit to a new branch called update-readme on the remote repository named origin?
After you have cloned a repository from a remote host, you now have
c: a local copy of the project in your filesystem.
the commit history for all files in the repository on your filesystem.
committed new files into the repository.
a: a local copy of the project in your filesystem.
the commit history for all files in the repository on your filesystem.

q: What’s the command to show the difference between your staged changes and the current version?
What is the difference between Git and GitHub?
c: GitHub is used for hosting Git projects.
GitHub has a hub, and Git does not.
GitLab, GitHub, and Git are different names for the same thing.
a: GitHub is used for hosting Git projects.

q: Which of these git commands can be used show the remote URL that is, git@github.com:bluecodemonks/go-hello-world.git) as well as the remote name (that is, origin)?
Which of these git commands can be used to create a new branch called feature/readme-update and switch to it?
Which statements are correct about branching? (Choose 2)
c: Branching is important only if you plan to merge changes from two independent projects.
A branching strategy needs to define types of branches and all rules governing usage by the developers.
Every developer must understand the strategy and agree to follow it.
Branching strategies must be agreed upon only by development team leads, not all developers.
a: A branching strategy needs to define types of branches and all rules governing usage by the developers.
Every developer must understand the strategy and agree to follow it.

q: Which git command can be used to stage the changes you made to update_iosxe.py to be included in the next commit?
Which scenario is more likely to cause a merge conflict?
c: Two developers open the same file.
A file gets deleted by one developer while it’s being modified by another developer.
All these scenarios are easily handled by Git.
a: A file gets deleted by one developer while it’s being modified by another developer.

q: What are cons of the branch and pull workflow?
c: All code contributors must have read-write access to the shared repository.
Overwriting of shared branches can occur.
The concept of forking needs to be understood.
The main branch needs to be forkable.
a: All code contributors must have read-write access to the shared repository.
Overwriting of shared branches can occur.

q: Which of the following attributes is true for git?
c: Git is distributed. Almost all operations are local to your system.
Git has integrity checks through checksums.
Git has a central repository hosted in GitHub.
a: Git is distributed. Almost all operations are local to your system.
Git has integrity checks through checksums.

q: The main benefit of a VCS is your ability to do what?
c: Manage code for multiple development projects.
Streamline the development cycle or process.
All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What is version control is used to track?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: After a pull request is submitted, the underlying code change can no longer be changed.
Which of these properties suits a branch and pull workflow? (Choose 3)
Which statement is most accurate when describing SOAP web services?
c: SOAP is defined as a JSON- and XML-based protocol.
SOAP is defined as an XML-based protocol.
SOAP has no error handling method.
SOAP is defined as an XML-based protocol and is stateless only.
a: SOAP is defined as an XML-based protocol.

q: The Content-Type header attribute specifies the format of data in the request body so that the receiver can parse it into the appropriate format. When you’re specifying the content types of the request body and output, what does using the Content-Type application/x-www-form-urlencoded do?
c: It indicates that the request body is encoded in key-value tuples.
It indicates that the request body format is multipart/form-data.
It sets the output type to XML.
It indicates that the request body format is XML.
a: It indicates that the request body is encoded in key-value tuples.

q: Which statement(s) is/are correct regarding an HTTP POST request in a RESTful architecture?
c: The POST method is usually associated with creating resources.
The POST method can be used to update a resource.
a: The POST method is usually associated with creating resources.

q: What does the acronym ACID stand for?
What is the Swagger UI?
c: The Swagger UI can be used to generate API documentation that can be used only via Python or Ansible.
The Swagger UI can be used to generate isolated API documentation that lets your users try out the API calls directly in the browser.
The Swagger UI can be used to generate interactive API documentation that lets your users try out the API calls directly in the browser.
The Swagger UI can be used to generate API code that lets your users try out the API calls directly in Postman.
a: The Swagger UI can be used to generate interactive API documentation that lets your users try out the API calls directly in the browser.

q: HTTP API methods are often referred to as “idempotent” or “not idempotent.” What does it mean for an HTTP method to be “idempotent”?
c: The request is dispatched to a potent machine for handling.
This method does not change or update the state of the resource.
The same request, using this method, can be made multiple times, and the result is the same as if only one request were made.
This method has been tested extensively
a: The same request, using this method, can be made multiple times, and the result is the same as if only one request were made.

q: When you issue an API call using the PATCH method, what does the request method supported by Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) do to the current resource?
What are some architectural styles for creating a Web API?
c: Simple URI as the address for the services
a: Simple URI as the address for the services

q: Which statement describes the advantages of gRPC? (Choose all that apply.)
c: It provides low-latency, highly scalable, distributed systems.
gRPC is a framework for implementing RPC APIs via HTTP/2.
A newly designed protocol needs to be accurate, efficient, and language independent.
Layered design enables extension; for example, authentication, load balancing, logging, and monitoring.
a: It provides low-latency, highly scalable, distributed systems.
gRPC is a framework for implementing RPC APIs via HTTP/2.
A newly designed protocol needs to be accurate, efficient, and language independent.
Layered design enables extension; for example, authentication, load balancing, logging, and monitoring.

q: What are REST and RESTful?
c: REST is an HTTP-based protocol that provides a programmatic interface for accessing data defined in YANG.
RESTful refers to web services written by applying REST architectural concepts; they are called RESTful services.
RESTful refers to web services that perform an RPC by sending an HTTP request to a server that implements XML-RPC and receives the HTTP response.
a: RESTful refers to web services written by applying REST architectural concepts; they are called RESTful services.

q: What are the ACID properties?
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the HTTP PUT method?
c: The HTTP PUT method is safe and does not impact resources.
The HTTP PUT method is idempotent; it is not safe and it impacts resources.
The HTTP PUT method is nonidempotent and it impacts resources per changes.
PUT removes all the resources and does not replace the data.
a: The HTTP PUT method is idempotent; it is not safe and it impacts resources.

q: Which of these statements about data representation formats are correct? (Choose 2)
c: XML stands for Extensive Markup Language (XML).
XML uses data binding and data serialization.
JSON stands for Java Simple Object Notation (JSON).
a: XML uses data binding and data serialization.

q: What is the difference between a synchronous and an asynchronous API?
c: An asynchronous API uses a push model to send event notifications.
A synchronous API does not wait for interaction.
API clients can subscribe to event notifications from asynchronous APIs.
Asynchronous APIs are always public APIs.
a: An asynchronous API uses a push model to send event notifications.
API clients can subscribe to event notifications from asynchronous APIs.

q: Which statement describes NETCONF/YANG?
c: NETCONF/YANG provides a standardized way to programmatically update and modify the configuration of a network device.
NETCONF/YANG provides a nonstandardized way to programmatically update and modify the configuration of a network device.
NETCONF/YANG provides a standardized way to programmatically update and modify only the startup configuration of a network device.
NETCONF/YANG provides an irreplaceable way to programmatically update and modify the configuration of a network device.
a: NETCONF/YANG provides a standardized way to programmatically update and modify the configuration of a network device.

q: HTTP API methods are often referred to as “safe” or “not safe.” What does it mean for an HTTP method to be “safe”?
c: This method is handled via a safe protocol such as HTTPS.
This method does not change or update the state of the resource.
This method can be applied multiple times to the same resource without different results.
This method has been tested extensively.
a: This method does not change or update the state of the resource.

q: Which of these are valid API types?
Which of these descriptions describes a remote-procedure call (RPC)?
c: Code functions are invoked on another server by sending XML or JSON-encoded command blocks.
Built on top of HTTP, it provides a uniform interface to access and modify resources.
It is a query language that allows the client to specify the exact properties to retrieve from an remote resource.
Using HTTP/HTTPS, this protocol is ACID-compliant.
a: Code functions are invoked on another server by sending XML or JSON-encoded command blocks.

q: What does the Content-Type header of an API request describe?
c: The expected format of the response
The type (for example, JSON or XML) of the payload enclosed in the request
The type of resource being accessed
The HTTP method used to make the request
a: The type (for example, JSON or XML) of the payload enclosed in the request

q: In an outside-in API design, which of the following statements are correct?
c: An API is built on-top of a fully functioning system.
Feedback from developers is gathered to shape the API to their needs.
a: Feedback from developers is gathered to shape the API to their needs.

q: Outside-in API design allows for a lot more elasticity than inside-out API design. Which of the following are advantages of this approach?
c: The UI is last to be built

q: An API client allows the client to abstract which of the following? (Choose 2)
What does page-based pagination allow the developer of the API to do? (Choose two.)
c: Choose to view the required number of pages
Choose to view the required range of pages
Use the previous or next feature when requesting pages
Return a pointer to a specific item in the dataset
a: Choose to view the required number of pages
Choose to view the required range of pages

q: HTTP methods should not be included in endpoints. True or False?
In an inside-out API design approach, which of the follow is correct?
c: The back-end infrastructure already exists within an organization and is used as a foundation for defining the API.
The back-end infrastructure does not exist within an organization.
The back-end infrastructure is built in tandem and will be used as a foundation for defining the API.
The back-end infrastructure is a mock server and is used as a foundation for defining the API.
a: The back-end infrastructure already exists within an organization and is used as a foundation for defining the API.

q: What is pagination?
c: The process of streaming data to the API consumer
The process of splitting long results into smaller chunks called pages
The splitting of long requests into multiple smaller requests called pages
The ability to page a resource for new events
a: The process of splitting long results into smaller chunks called pages

q: What is the OpenAPI Specification (OAS)?
c: OAS defines a standard, programming language[nd]agnostic interface description for all APIs.
OAS defines a standard, programming language[nd]agnostic interface description for GraphQL.
OAS defines a standard, programming language[nd]agnostic interface description for REST APIs.
OAS defines a standard, programming language[nd]agnostic interface description for REST and RPC API.
a: OAS defines a standard, programming language[nd]agnostic interface description for REST APIs.

q: A WebSocket uses a bidirectional protocol, in which there are no predefined message patterns such as request/response. The client and the server can send messages to each other. True or False?
Which of these endpoints (and corresponding HTTP methods) adhere to naming best practices when it comes to designing RESTful APIs?
Which of these authentication methods uses a username-password combination to authenticate against the API?
What statements about cursor-based pagination are true?
c: This type of pagination is suited for fast-changing data.
A cursor to an item is returned, and the API returns a set of subsequent items.
Cursor and offset-based pagination are mutually exclusive.
a: This type of pagination is suited for fast-changing data.
A cursor to an item is returned, and the API returns a set of subsequent items.

q: What is a refresh token used for in an OAuth2 flow?
c: Programmatically retrieving a new access token without prompting the user
Refreshing the current access token to be valid longer
Triggering the OAuth2 flow to be required again the next time the token is used
a: Programmatically retrieving a new access token without prompting the user

q: What can be done with the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) of an API?
c: Generate SDKs in various programming languages

q: Which of the following are API rate-limiter techniques and algorithms for measuring and limiting rates?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: An OAuth2.0 bearer token is an opaque string that is ______________.
c: A multiple string, which acts as the authentication of the API request
Intended to have meaning to clients using it
Not intended to have any meaning to clients using it
a: Not intended to have any meaning to clients using it

q: What python command can be used to install a Swagger-generated python SDK into your environment (without using pip – dependencies are installed)?
What are the tasks of the authorization server in an OAuth2 flow? (Choose 3)
c: Issue access tokens to the application
a: Issue access tokens to the application

q: What does a software development kit (SDK) help speed up and improve?
c: Adoption and developer experience of an API
Adoption and modification of an API
a: Adoption and developer experience of an API

q: What platform provides an API-driven platform on which to run, manage, operate, and schedule containerized workloads within an enterprise?

When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor is used to ensure that any service that exposes a north-bound service should be explicitly declared and exposed on the individual host?

When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor focuses on keeping as little a gap as possible between code being committed to the main repository and it being moved into a deployed state?

When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor states that external constants should be abstracted away from the code so that it can be released to the public without compromise of sensitive information?
Which phase of the CI/CD pipeline is typically associated with limiting the number of users affected if an issue occurs during a rollout?
What is the purpose of continuous integration?
c: To integrate new code into production
To add new features to an existing application
To integrate user feedback into the code development process
To build/compile, test, and secure code
a: To build/compile, test, and secure code

q: Where do DevOps and SRE principles overlap?
c: They bring in new people to institute process changes.
Adoption in changes of process ensure uptime, availability, and understanding of the many-faceted nature of application deployment.
They don’t overlap; they are two conceptually different concepts.
Change is enforced from a cultural shift at the top of an organization with no new personnel.
a: Adoption in changes of process ensure uptime, availability, and understanding of the many-faceted nature of application deployment.

q: When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor focuses on defining code services that should be compiled at runtime and be immutable unless another build, release, or run cycle is performed?
Which of the following is not a valid application CD release strategy?

When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor helps describe a release strategy that creates a clear separation of the app and its features and should not be able to change the code on which it was originally invoked?
When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor states a codebase must be in a VCS repository and should be the single source of truth for all deployments?
What is a 12-factor app?
c: Twelve areas of unit testing that an application undergoes before being moved to production
Twelve aspects of the user experience that every app should adhere to
Twelve tests of security and application functionality to be performed during a CI/CD pipeline build
Twelve best-practice recommendations on designing and delivering a web-based application
a: Twelve best-practice recommendations on designing and delivering a web-based application

q: When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor identifies ancillary functions that perform maintenance, administration, or other duties that are not invoked within the applications execution?
When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor seeks to remove a process from the worker queue if the scaled worker process no longer responds or times out?
Which Google cloud product offers managed Kubernetes within its suite of offers and tools?
What does a serverless infrastructure provide to an end user?
c: Operations and management of the server platform and its underlying dependencies are removed.
All of these answers are correct.
a: Operations and management of the server platform and its underlying dependencies are removed.

q: When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor states that external constants should be abstracted away from the code so that it can be used across development, test, and production environments with a simple change of the configuration, while the code is still the same?
What data format or language is typically used to build CI/CD pipeline definitions?
What is the core tenet of DevOps?
c: A spreading of work to limit failure domains
Training operations teams to write code
A cultural shift focused on empathy and understanding
a: A cultural shift focused on empathy and understanding

q: Which statements about cloud abstraction are true? (Choose 2)
c: More abstraction requires less management of the underlying compute for the application.
More abstraction provides more flexibility in how the code is deployed and run.
More abstraction requires more management of the underlying compute for the application.
More abstraction provides less flexibility in how the code is deployed and run.
a: More abstraction requires less management of the underlying compute for the application.
More abstraction provides less flexibility in how the code is deployed and run.

q: Which method in the CI/CD pipeline deployment phase is used to update the application in a serial fashion where users could potentially encounter different versions depending on how network traffic is set?
When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor states that all branching, edits, and deployments should be done from the same repository?
When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor focuses on the ability to monitor and ensure the proper function or performance of the application?
When following the 12-factor app Software Practices for Operability, which factor helps define a demarcation where the prior and future release of the app is unique in its features and support?
The term data states refers to data being _________.
c: In a relational or nonrelational database
a: In a relational or nonrelational database

q: Which of the following is not a cryptographic attack?

Which user input would result in an injection attack with the following code?

read (user_name)

query = "SELECT * FROM users_data WHERE user = '" + user_name + "';

db.execute(query)
What is a certificate authority’s main function?
When an application needs to use multiple credentials to access various systems, what is the safest and most convenient method to securely store these secrets?
c: Store credentials directly in the application code
Store credentials at a syncing service
Store credentials in the password-protected spreadsheet
a: Store credentials at a syncing service

q: What does data at rest mean?
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What is the difference between a two-legged authorization flow and a four-legged one?
c: The two-legged one utilizes an authorization server.
The four-legged one takes longer to execute.
There is no such thing as a four-legged authorization.
a: There is no such thing as a four-legged authorization.

q: What does the information security CIA triad stand for?
c: None of these answers are correct.

q: Which of the following is NOT a valid method to protect code and database against injection?
Information system security can be summed up in three fundamental components. Which one is not one of them?
GDPR is a data protection law in the EU; what does it stand for?
c: None of these answers are correct.

q: IT secrets are all the following except _________.
Which of the following is considered to be an injection attack? (Choose all that apply.)
c: All of these answers are correct.
a: All of these answers are correct.

q: What does PII refer to?
c: None of these answers are correct.

q: Which of the following is an example of data in motion?

Stored user credentials on the unencrypted file system
Stored user credentials on the encrypted file system
Transcoding video file in memory from one format into another
a: Synchronization between members of the isolated database cluster

q: Which of the following is true about OAuth 2.0 three-legged authorization?
c: In the first "leg," the client authenticates with the authorization server and requests an access token.
In the second "leg," the client exchanges the authorization code for an access token with the authorization server.
In the third "leg," the client authenticates the resource server with the authorization code.
In the fourth "leg," the client sends the access token to the resource server to request protected resources.
a: In the second "leg," the client exchanges the authorization code for an access token with the authorization server.

a: The root CA self-signs its certificate.

q: Traditional CLI network device configuration is an example of
How does NETCONF handle security at the transport level?
c: NETCONF was insecure initially, but version 3 introduced both authentication and encryption.
NETCONF RFC stipulates that connection must be encrypted with SSH.
NETCONF connections may be encrypted with TLS or SSH.
NETCONF support for TLS encryption was discontinued due to breaches in it.

q: What is a key characteristic of model-driven configuration management?
c: Model-driven management reflects relationships across deployed networks and nodes to configure accurate intent.
Model-driven management treats networks and devices with segmentation.
Model-driven management applies to the RC hobby industry.
Model-driven management uses inference engines to dynamically generate configuration parameters.
a: Model-driven management reflects relationships across deployed networks and nodes to configure accurate intent.

q: Which of the following is a feature of model-driven configuration management?
c: Partial configuration fragments may be left on devices in case of deployment failures.
It maintains an awareness and understanding of interdependencies among the devices.
Generally, it refers to specific devices.
It does not maintain an awareness or understanding of interdependencies among the devices.
a: It maintains an awareness and understanding of interdependencies among the devices.

q: Which content-encoding format is supported by NETCONF?
Which of the following is NOT a feature of model-driven configuration management?
c: It abstracts the individual device configurations in favor of the deployment of a service or feature.
Deployment is either fully successful, or it is rolled back or removed entirely.
Partial configuration fragments may be left on devices in case of deployment failures.
It maintains an awareness and understanding of interdependencies among the devices.
a: Partial configuration fragments may be left on devices in case of deployment failures.

c: None of these answers are correct.

q: What of the following is true when comparing NETCONF and RESTCONF?
c: NETCONF uses YANG to model device configuration, while RESTCONF uses JSON.
RESTCONF is missing the multiple datastore functionality of NETCONF.
NETCONF is missing configuration locking functionality.
RESTCONF supports only JSON encoding, whereas NETCONF supports both XML and JSON.
a: RESTCONF is missing the multiple datastore functionality of NETCONF.

q: What RFCs defined NETCONF, initially and lately?
What IETF working group worked on YANG, and what function does it provide?
c: NETCONF; it serves as a data abstraction protocol that serves to normalize firmware images.
NETCONF; it provides a complementary encoding method to YIN.
NETMOD; it serves as a data modeling language to characterize configuration, state, and administrative functions.
NETMOD; it is the next-generation availability monitoring protocol that extends ICMP ping.
a: NETMOD; it serves as a data modeling language to characterize configuration, state, and administrative functions.

q: Which modes exist for the model-driven telemetry? (Choose 2)
Which MDT policy is most frugal with disk space and overhead processing?
What is true when comparing model-driven telemetry (MDT) with SNMP or syslog?

Syslog messages are easily readable and are structured for an easy programmatic consumption.
Both MDT and SNMP deliver their messages reliably using UDP transport.
gRPC MDT data is secured by using TLS by default.
a: gRPC MDT data is secured by using TLS by default.

a: Issue show yang sensors from the CLI.

a: Sensor paths come from YANG models.

a: Perform periodic resource polling using SNMP

SNMPv3 data security is similar to MDT data security.
a: SNMPv3 data security is similar to MDT data security.

q: What is true about a TIG stack in regard to telemetry processing?

a: It is a set of independent open-source products commonly used together.

q: What is true about dial-out mode?
c: The lifetime of the subscription is tied to the connection that created it.
The subscription is a part of the device's running configuration.
The controller tracks session state and reestablishes subscription in case of disconnect.
Telemetry updates are sent to the session initiator (subscriber).
a: The subscription is a part of the device's running configuration.

q: Which streaming telemetry encoding receiver cannot interpret key names without some additional information?
What is an optimal way to evaluate disk usage with model-driven telemetry?
c: Add the number of network elements and multiply by 1480 bytes.
Baseline the telemetry consumption for a time period and extrapolate.
Use the IEFT Telemetry calculator from RFC 2795.
a: Baseline the telemetry consumption for a time period and extrapolate.

q: What is true about dial-in mode?
c: Subscriptions automatically reconnect to the receiver after a reload or stateful switchover.
The subscription ID is 0 in all dial-in sessions.
Telemetry data is sent to the session initiator (subscriber).
The subscription remains active until it is removed from the device configuration.
a: Telemetry data is sent to the session initiator (subscriber).

q: Which streaming telemetry encoding format is most efficient in terms of resulting data size?
MDT gRPC uses which application protocol?
What is a sensor path?
c: A combination of SNMP MIB object and interface
The pathway from managed element to receiving telemetry collector

a: A combination of YANG data model and metric node

q: Considering MDT dial-out mode, which statement is true?
c: The device is the client and source pushing data; the telemetry receiver is the server.
The device is passive; the telemetry receiver initiates the connection, requesting the data.
The device is active; the telemetry receiver initiates the connection, requesting the data.
The device is the server; the telemetry receiver is the client.
The device maintains no configuration; the telemetry receiver updates the subscriptions to the device.
a: The device is the client and source pushing data; the telemetry receiver is the server.

q: What are examples of model-driven telemetry (MDT)?
c: Interface down notification within a NETCONF session
GPB-encoded interface utilization information sent at regular intervals
Interface down syslog event message sent to a central collector
NETCONF get-config response from a device
a: Interface down notification within a NETCONF session

q: What is true about dial-in mode?
c: Subscription is a part of the device's running configuration.
Session duration is negotiated during subscription establishment.
The subscription ID is dynamically generated upon successful establishment of a subscription.
The session is automatically reestablished in case of disconnect.
a: The subscription ID is dynamically generated upon successful establishment of a subscription.
